dt: {bc}not being or acting in accord with laws, rules, or established custom
{bc}not conforming to the usual pattern of inflection
{bc}not following a usual or prescribed procedure
{bc}celebrated without either proclamation of the banns or publication of intention to marry
{bc}not belonging to or a part of a regular organized group
{bc}not belonging to a regular army but raised for a special purpose
{bc}having one or more floral parts of the same whorl different in size, shape, or arrangement
{bc}lacking continuity or regularity especially of occurrence or activity

pt: {sc}irregular{/sc} {sc}anomalous{/sc} {sc}unnatural{/sc} mean not conforming to rule, law, or custom. {sc}irregular{/sc} implies not conforming to a law or regulation imposed for the sake of uniformity in method, practice, or conduct.
{sc}anomalous{/sc} implies not conforming to what might be expected because of the class or type to which it belongs or the laws that govern its existence.

pt.t: her drive made her an {it}anomalous{/it} figure in a sleepy organization

pt: {sc}unnatural{/sc} suggests what is contrary to nature or to principles or standards felt to be essential to the well-being of civilized society.

et: Middle English {it}irreguler{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin {it}irregularis{/it} not in accordance with rule, from Latin {it}in-{/it} + {it}regularis{/it} regular
shortdef: not being or acting in accord with laws, rules, or established custom
not conforming to the usual pattern of inflection; specifically : strong
not following a usual or prescribed procedure; especially, British : celebrated without either proclamation of the banns or publication of intention to marry
